children.description: "It is a holder for propositional attitudes"
children.name: Agent

children.description: "An organisation is a group of other organisations or persons which acts 'as one'. An organisation can be both formal (i.e. created by law or decree) or informal."
children.name: Organisation

children.description: "A person is an individual agent. Usually associated with 'human being'."
children.name: Person

children.description: "A medium is a bearer of expressions, i.e. externalised propositions. Propositions become expressions once they are externalised through some medium."
children.name: Medium

children.description: "A Document bears some (and only) expression(s) stated by some statement in writing."
children.name: Document

children.description:
"A legal entity is a natural person or a legal construct through which the law allows a group of natural persons to act as if it were a single composite individual for certain purposes. The most common purposes are lawsuits, property ownership, and contracts. Sometimes referred to as corporate personhood or legal personality, this concept allows for easy conduct of business by having ownership, lawsuits, and agreements under the name of the legal entity instead of the several names of the people making up the entity.

A legal entity is not necessarily distinct from the natural persons of which it is composed. Most legal entities are simply amalgamations of the persons that make it up for convenience's sake. A legal entity that does have a separate existence from its members is called a company or corporation. This distinction gives the corporation its unique perpetual succession privilege and is usually also the source of the limited liability of corporate members. Some other legal entities also enjoy limited liability of members, but not on account of separate existence (Source: Wikipedia.org)"
children.name: Legal_Person

children.description: "A legal person as defined in private law"
children.name: Private_Legal_Person

children.description: "A voluntary association (also sometimes called an unincorporated association, or just an association) is a group of individuals who voluntarily enter into an agreement to form a body (or organization) to accomplish a purpose."
children.name: Association

children.description: "A company refers to a legal entity formed which has a separate legal identity from its members, and is ordinarily incorporated to undertake commercial business. Although some jurisdictions refer to unincorporated entities as companies, in most jurisdictions the term refers only to incorporated entities. "
children.name: Company

children.description: "A limited company is a corporation whose liability is limited by law"
children.name: Limited_Company

children.description: "Similar to the US corporation, offers several advantages over trading as sole trader."
children.name: Public_Limited_Company

children.description: "A corporation is a legal entity which, while being composed of natural persons, exists completely separately from them. This separation gives the corporation unique powers which other legal entities lack. "
children.name: Corporation

children.description: "A kind of (philanthropic) organization, set up as a legal entity either by individuals or institutions, with the purpose of distributing grants to support causes in line with the goals of the foundation"
children.name: Foundation

children.description: "An organisation formed into a legal corporation"
children.name: Incorporated

children.description: "An organized group of people associated together for religious, benevolent, cultural, scientific, political, patriotic, or other purposes."
children.name: Society

children.description: "An autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social, and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly-owned and democratically-controlled enterprise."
children.name: Co-operative

children.description: "A public body or body created by an act of law to serve a public interest"
children.name: Public_Body

children.description: "A legislature is a type of (representative) deliberative assembly with the power to adopt laws."
children.name: Legislative_Body

children.description: "A legal speech act creates some propositional attitude towards a legal expression."
children.name: Legal_Speech_Act

children.description: "Act of law: a public act by a legislative body which creates an expression with legal status; the legal status depends on the jurisdiction of the legislative body."
children.name: Act_of_Law

children.description: "A public act that attributes a power to perform a public act to a public body."
children.name: Assignment

children.description: "NOTE: Cannot express that the 'promised' act corresponds to the act qualified by the statement in writing"
children.name: Decision

children.description: "Delegate: entrust a task or responsibility to some other person"
children.name: Delegation

children.description: "A public act is an act by some Person or Organisation which creates (at least) a communicated attitude (and thereby an expression)"
children.name: Public_Act

children.description: "Mandate: give (someone) authority to act in a certain way"
children.name: Mandate

children.description: "A legal role is a role played in a legal context. Legal role players can be both Agents and other 'things'"
children.name: Legal_Role

children.description: "A social legal role is played by some agent in the context of legal activities."
children.name: Social_Legal_Role

children.description: "A professional legal role is a legal profession of some person, examples: lawyer, judge etc."
children.name: Professional_Legal_Role

children.description: "An LKIF rule, based on swrl:Impl"
children.name: Rule

children.description: "A valid LKIF rule"
children.name: Valid_Rule

children.description: "A plan is a structure of multiple other plans or actions. These can be both sequential or concurrent. Usually a plan is referred to in the context of the intention to act of some agent, however when executed the plan itself comes into effect."
children.name: Plan

children.description: "A collaborative plan is a plan which is shared (and executed) between at least two agents a and b."
children.name: Collaborative_Plan

children.description: "A transaction is an exchange or interaction between at least two agents a and b. Consists of two actions A and B where a is the actor of action A and the recipient of action B, and vice versa. Usually these actions are performed concurrently, but these may also be done consequently."
children.name: Transaction

children.description: "A trade is an exchange of some things between two agents a and b. Consists of two actions A and B where a is the actor of action A and the recipient of action B, and vice versa. Usually these actions are performed concurrently, but these may also be done consequently. The ownership of the things being traded is the requirement/result pair for each action."
children.name: Trade

children.description: "A personal plan is a plan which is held (and can be executed) by at most one agent."
children.name: Personal_Plan

children.description: "NOTE: In previous versions of this ontology, this class was called 'Qualified'. In lieu of the separation between Proposition and Propositional_Attitude, the intended meaning of that class has been moved to 'Evaluative_Proposition'"
children.name: Proposition

children.description: "Some thing which is evaluatively qualified, i.e. an evaluation applies to the proposition, the proposition is judged. The proposition is comparable to some other proposition."
children.name: Evaluative_Proposition

children.description: "An expression is a proposition beared by some medium, e.g. a document, and is stated by some communicated attitude"
children.name: Expression

children.description: "A propositional attitude connects a person (the holder of the attitude) to some proposition, in fact it expresses some qualification over the proposition. Distinguishing a proposition from the propositional content expressed by it is necessary when properties relating to the thing expressed and properties of the expression itself must be distinguished. For LKIF the distinction between Belief, Intention, Qualification, and Observation is relevant. The distinction between belief/expectation, intention, and observation is relevant for i.a. establishing mens rea (guilty mind). The distinction between beliefs (expressing the content of the mind of an agent) and statements (expressing the content of an act of communication by an agent) is classical."
children.name: Propositional_Attitude

children.description: "Someting an agent 'believes in', i.e. holds as true"
children.name: Belief

children.description: "A communictated attitude is a propositional attitude involved in an act of communication."
children.name: Communicated_Attitude

children.description: "The assertion is subject to a fit between words and world, in Searle's terms. It's propositional content can be true of false. If it is inconsistent with other assertions, beliefs, observations, it may come to be considered false."
children.name: Assertion

children.description: "An assertion that is inconsistent with the beliefs of the speaker. It is *intentionally* false."
children.name: Lie

children.description: "Searle: the successful performance of a declaration is sufficient to bring about the fit between words and world, to make the propositional content true. In other words, if there is an inconsistency between the declaration and assertions, beliefs, or observations, it is not the declaration that is false. True of definitions and norms, and several other performative statements by legislators."
children.name: Declaration

children.description: "A promise is a communicated attitude about some future action or state"
children.name: Promise

children.description: "Not to be confused with the actual writing/document itself, which is the medium of the statement."
children.name: Statement_In_Writing

children.description: "A feeling of wanting"
children.name: Desire

children.description: "An evaluative attitude expresses e.g. a judgment. The proposition qualified by the evaluative attitude is comparable to something else."
children.name: Evaluative_Attitude

children.description: "Intention is where the agent expects certain consequences of his or her actions and desires those consequences to occur. This concept must be related to qualification and preference in some way."
children.name: Intention

children.description: "A qualification expresses e.g. a judgment. The thing qualified by the qualification is comparable to something else."
children.name: Qualification

children.description: "A mental, i.e. non-physical, process that has no physical effects. Examples are (human) thought and reasoning."
children.name: Mental_Process

children.description: "A subjective entity is ontologically subjective, i.e. its existence is relative to an observer, that attributes its properties to some other entity, given a context.  "
children.name: Subjective_Entity

children.description: "A role is a specification of default behavior and accompanying expectations of the thing 'playing' the role. Similar to actors in a theater who play roles, but are not the roles. Example: student."
children.name: Role

children.description: "proposes something that usually is the case, although there is no specific evidence that it is true in this particular case"
children.name: Assumption

children.description: "A cause is an epistemic role played by something which is the outcome of a (chain) of processes"
children.name: Cause

children.description: "Observation and/or statement, used as a backing for a belief. Evidence is the role of observation which is qualified by some belief."
children.name: Evidence

children.description: "An exception is something that is excluded from a general statement or does not follow a rule. In LKIF rules, an exception is a rule which has an exception relation to another rule (cf. Deliverable 1.1)"
children.name: Exception

children.description: "An expectation is a predictive belief held on purely logical grounds, i.e. not based on direct external evidence, like an observation or a statement by another agent. It is also often characterized as a "belief about the future", but this isn't very helpful since one may also hold expectations about the (yet unknown) past. The theory of evolution is for instance a fertile ground for predictions about the existence of past species, and therefore at the same a predictor of future observations."
children.name: Expectation

children.description: "A fact is a proposition (about something) which is (commonly) agreed upon to hold as true: it has some backing in evidence"
children.name: Fact

children.description: "An observation is the role played by some proposition believed to be true or false through observation of an agent."
children.name: Observation

children.description: "NOTE: This currently cannot be expressed: OWL DL does not support negation of properties. The definition will be further elaborated once OWL 1.1 is supported by development tools."
children.name: Problem

children.description: "A surprise is an observation that deviates from an expectation."
children.name: Surprise

children.description: "Teleological counterpart of cause"
children.name: Reason

children.description: "An argument is a reason that is expressed through some medium"
children.name: Argument

children.description: "The use or purpose of some object as used in some context."
children.name: Function

children.description: "played_by all (action:Agent and (action:actor_in some (action:Action and (plays some expression:Expectation))))"
children.name: Social_Role

children.description: "A role which has a meaning in the context of an organisation: i.e. the role defines a 'position' within sthe structure of roles within an organisation"
children.name: Organisation_Role

children.description: "A role played by some person (i.e. not an organisation)"
children.name: Person_Role

children.description: "A consequence of our clear separation of ontology from models of situations (occurrences), is well exemplified in the two ways we look at time and space. Things happen against the canvas of space and time. This 3D canvas moving in time (or whatever metaphor) allows us to index instances of objects and processes. Time and space provide positions in time and space for objects. Positions are in general modeled in some mereological framework. However, the objects and processes as classes have time and space properties in a different way. Space occupied by an object is its inherent property of size or extension. This property was for Descartes even the critical one that separated mental (not: abstract) objects from physical ones. Processes occupy (consume) time; they take some duration. This time resource is inversely related to the consumption of energy. This distinction between position and extension is also made in various other ontologies. However, this distinction is easily obscured by the fact that the extension of an object can also be used as a reference for location. An object can be in another object. In fact, any physical object can be used as a spatial and even temporal referent. This does not refute our view that locations are occurrences. To be precise: extension is an inherent, necessary property of a physical object or process; its location is an accidental one."
children.name: Occurrence

children.description: "An occurrence in space-time"
children.name: Spatio_Temporal_Occurrence

children.description: "A place is a spatio-temporal-occurrence"
children.name: Place

children.description: "An absolute place is defined without reference to other places."
children.name: Absolute_Place

children.description: "A location complex only overlaps its own parts (OWL 1.1)"
children.name: Location_Complex

children.description: "A place is comprehensive if it always covers every place (and thus also every location-complex) and every object."
children.name: Comprehensive_Place

children.description: "A relative place is defined by some reference to some object/thing"
children.name: Relative_Place

children.description:
"An abstract concept is a concept which does not (necessarily) have a referent in either the physical or the mental world.   

Abstract entities are (proto)mathematical, formal entities, entities which have a purely formal, logical or mathematical meaning.

As all concepts are abstractions, one may argue that a separate abstract world is difficult to see. In common-sense, a circle has more properties and is less abstract than in mathematics. Even mathematicians marvel about the fact their pure abstractions enable us to predict very concrete things. However, we are not directly concerned with these mappings. The most important is that common-sense knows about a (small) number of proto-mathematical concepts, such as collections, sequences and count-numbers (positive integers). We know also about geometric simplifications such as line, circle, square, cube, etc. These common sense notions might even be the real roots of our mathematics. However, these kind of semi-formal abstractions do not play a very central role in law, and therefore LRI-Core is thinly populated with abstract classes."
children.name: Abstract_Entity

children.description: "An atom is the most basic (undivisible) part of an LKIF rule (cf. Deliverable 1.1)"
children.name: Atom

children.description: "A moment is an atomic period of time, i.e. it cannot be divided into other parts"
children.name: Moment

children.description: "A part is a part_of some whole"
children.name: Part

children.description: "A whole has at least some part"
children.name: Whole

children.description: "A composition has multiple parts, the components should meet"
children.name: Composition

children.description: "A composition of exactly two parts"
children.name: Pair

children.description: "A pair of two time periods"
children.name: Pair_Of_Periods

children.description: "An interval is a composition of multiple periods of time."
children.name: Interval

children.description: "The collective memory of some group of agents, i.e. propositions beared by custom are shared (i.e. held) by all members of the group"
children.name: Custom

children.description: "In law, custom, or customary law consists of established patterns of behaviour that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting."
children.name: Customary_Law

children.description: "Legal expressions are created by  some legal speech act and qualified by a communicated attitude"
children.name: Legal_Expression

children.description: "A definition in a legal context (for example “x means y” or “by x it is meant y”);"
children.name: Definitional_Expression

children.description: "A legal evaluative expression asserts that something is good or bad, is a value to be optimised or an evil to be minimised (for example “human dignity is value”, “participation ought to be promoted”);"
children.name: Evaluative_Expression

children.description: "Establishes or terminates the existence of a legal entity (for example “the company ceases to exist”);"
children.name: Existential_Expression

children.description: "Attributes a power to some agent (for example “a worker has the power to terminate his work contract”);"
children.name: Potestative_Expression

children.description: "We say that j has the declarative power to realize A to mean that if j declares A, then it is legally valid that A. For example, if x has the declarative power to terminate y’s obligation toward x to do then if x declares that y’s obligation toward x finishes, then it is legally valid that this obligation finishes."
children.name: Declarative_Power

children.description: "An enabling power is used in cases where the law aims at enabling some agent to produce an effect in a particular way."
children.name: Enabling_Power

children.description:
"A potestative right is an enabling power which is meant to benefit the holder of the power. For example, if some animal y does not 
belong to anybody, then x has the potestative-right to start x’s ownership of the animal,  by capturing y."
children.name: Potestative_Right

children.description: "A hohfeldian power covers any action which determines a legal effect."
children.name: Hohfeldian_Power

children.description: "An action-power consists in a generic power to produce a legal effect through an action determining it. Also called Subjections"
children.name: Action_Power

children.description: "Also called Disabilities"
children.name: Immunity

children.description: "Ascribes a legal role to a person or an object (for example,  “x is a citizen”, “x is an intellectual work”, “x is a technical invention”);"
children.name: Qualificatory_Expression

children.description: "A legal source is a source for legal statements, both norms and legal expressions. In a sense it is literally a 'source' of law"
children.name: Legal_Source

children.description: "An agreement entered into by actors in international law, namely states and international organizations. "
children.name: International_Agreement

children.description: "Some international agreement that is not binding under international law"
children.name: Non-binding_International_Agreement

children.description: "A resolution is a written motion adopted by a deliberative body. The substance of the resolution can be anything that can normally be proposed as a motion."
children.name: Resolution

children.description: "A treaty is a binding agreement under international law entered into by actors in international law, namely states and international organizations. Treaties are called by several names: treaties, international agreements, protocols, covenants, conventions, exchanges of letters, exchanges of notes, etc."
children.name: Treaty

children.description: "Legal doctrine is a framework, set of rules, procedural steps, or test, often established through precedent in the common law, through which judgments can be determined in a given legal cas"
children.name: Legal_Doctrine

children.description: "A legal document is a document bearing norms or normative statements. By virtue of this definition the norm-as-propositional-attitude is reified as norm-as proposition. In other words, the norm being expressed through the legal source is an expression of the propositional attitude."
children.name: Legal_Document

children.description: "A legal code bears one or more norms, all of which are uttered by some legislative body. It cannot bear expressions which are not uttered by a legislative body."
children.name: Code

children.description: "a code outlining the responsibilities of or best practice for an individual or organisation, such as a set of principles of good corporate behaviour adopted by a business\"
children.name: Code_of_Conduct

children.description: "A contract bears one or more norms, all of which are uttered by some natural person or legal person. It cannot bear expressions which are uttered by a different kind of agent."
children.name: Contract

children.description: "The word decree is often used as a derogative term for any authoritarian decision"
children.name: Decree

children.description: "Examples are European Union directive, a legislative act of the European Union and Directives, used by United States Government agencies (particularly the Department of Defense) to convey policies, responsibilities, and procedures."
children.name: Directive

children.description: "A regulation bears one or more norms, all of which are uttered by some legislative body. It cannot bear expressions which are not uttered by a legislative body."
children.name: Regulation

children.description: "A statute bears one or more norms, all of which are uttered by some legal person. It cannot bear expressions which are uttered by a different kind of agent."
children.name: Statute

children.description: "In law, a precedent or authority is a legal case establishing a principle or rule that a court may need to adopt when deciding subsequent cases with similar issues or facts. The term may also refer to the collective body of case law that a court should consider when interpreting the law. When a precedent establishes an important legal principle, or represents new or changed law on a particular issue, that precedent is often known as a landmark decision."
children.name: Precedent

children.description: "In law, a binding precedent (also mandatory precedent or binding authority) is a precedent which must be followed by all lower courts. It is usually created by the decision of a higher court, such as the House of Lords in the United Kingdom. Binding precedent relies on the legal principle of stare decisis."
children.name: Mandatory_Precedent

children.description: "In law, a persuasive precedent or advisory precedent is a precedent that need not be followed under the legal principle of stare decisis, but is nevertheless followed. Sources of persuasive precedent include the obiter dicta in the judgment of a court whose judgment would otherwise be binding, and the judgments of courts in other jurisdictions where the facts and/or legal system are similar to the case at hand. If a superior court adopts a persuasive precedent, it may become binding in the jurisdiction."
children.name: Persuasive_Precedent

children.description: "A proclamation (Lat. proclamare, to make public by announcement) is an official declaration."
children.name: Proclamation

children.description: "The term "soft law" refers to quasi-legal instruments which do not have any binding force, or whose binding force is somewhat "weaker" than the binding force of traditional law, often referred to as "hard law", in this context. The term "soft law" initially appeared in the area of international law, but more recently it has been transferred to other branches of law."
children.name: Soft_Law

children.description: "International Arbitration is the established method today for resolving disputes between parties to international commercial agreements. As with arbitration generally, it is a creature of contract, i.e., the parties' decision to submit any disputes to private adjudication by one or more arbitrators appointed in accordance with rules the parties themselves have agreed to adopt, usually by including a provision for the same in their contract. The practice of international arbitration has developed so as to allow parties from different legal and cultural backgrounds to resolve their disputes, generally without the formalities of their underlying legal systems."
children.name: International_Arbitration

children.description: "A norm is a kind of Qualification. A qualification which normatively qualifies some thing (i.e. some normatively qualified): i.e. a qualification which allows or disallows some thing."
children.name: Norm

children.description: "Permission allows propositions, to which therefore the predication Allowed applies. The thing(s) allowed is/are a subset of the thing(s) qualified by the permission. If S then P(A) means that S is qualified and S and A is allowed."
children.name: Permission

children.description: "See prohibition"
children.name: Obligation

children.description: "Prohibition obliges/allows thing(s), to which therefore the predication Obliged applies, and disallows thing(s), to which therefore the predication Disallowed applies. The union of the thing(s) allowed and the thing(s) disallowed is qualified by the prohibition. The things allowed and disallowed by the prohibition are disjoint (and completely partition the space of things qualified). If S then O(A) means that S is qualified, S and A is obliged/allowed, and S and not A is disallowed. If S then F(A) means that S is qualified, S and A is disallowed, and S and not A is obliged/allowed. The difference between Obligation and Prohibition is in which part of the partition of the qualified space is explicitly described by the normative statement. Alternative label: directive"
children.name: Prohibition

children.description: "A right is the legal or moral entitlement to do or refrain from doing something or to obtain or refrain from obtaining an action, thing or recogition in civil society."
children.name: Right

children.description: "A liability right expresses some right to act that brings with it some liability to perform another (compensating) act. For instance, if some k performs the permitted action A, then k will have to perform another action B for the benefit of j."
children.name: Liability_Right

children.description: "When, for the benefit of a person, this person is both permitted to perform and to omit an action – that is, when the action is facultative – we can say that he or she has a liberty right with regard to that action."
children.name: Liberty_Right

children.description: "Directed obligative ought-to-do are also called obligative rights. k has the obligative  right that j does A iff it is obligatory, toward k, that j does A. An example of obligative  right is “it is obligatory, toward Mary, that Tom pays 1,000 euro to John”"
children.name: Obligative_Right

children.description:
"An exclusionary right concerns the prohibition against performing certain inferences (against reasoning in certain ways), or 
against using certain kinds of premises for certain purposes, in the interest of a particular person. This is especially the case with anti-discrimination rules."
children.name: Exclusionary_Right

children.description: "The  negation of a directed obligation is a directed permission. However, it counts as a right,  namely, a permissive right, only when such negation is aimed at benefitting the author of  the permitted action. "
children.name: Permissive_Right

children.description: "Some thing which is qualified (allowed, disallowed) by a norm, i.e. a norm applies to the thing. Taking the principle of deontic choice to mean that the utterer of a normative statement intends to influence choices made by the addressee of the statement, the qualified thing should is comparable to some alternative. Note that Qualified does not partition into Allowed and Disallowed. Firstly, things can be Allowed by one Norm and Disallowed by another one. Secondly, the logical complement of the thing allowed by a permission is qualified (as worse or equal than the thing allowed), but neither allowed nor disallowed."
children.name: Normatively_Qualified

children.description: "See normatively qualified. Alternative labels: permitted, sanctioned, let, licensed."
children.name: Allowed

children.description: "Something which is both allowed and disallowed through some norm"
children.name: Allowed_And_Disallowed

children.description: "Is allowed by an Obligation, i.e. the alternative is strictly_worse according to the Obligation. Alternative labels: directed, commanded."
children.name: Obliged

children.description: "Loose end."
children.name: Strictly_Allowed

children.description: "See Qualified. Alternative labels: violation, prohibited, forbidden"
children.name: Disallowed

children.description: "Loose end."
children.name: Strictly_Disallowed

children.description:
"The physical world evolves around two main classes: physical objects and processes.

In lkif-core, the physical world evolves around two main classes: physical objects and processes. Objects are pieces of matter, while matter is typed by substances. Objects have mass, extension, viz. form and aggregation state (which limits form). Objects are the specification of the notion that matter, and in particular solid objects, is what makes the physical world relatively stable and observable. We define (physical) situations in the first place by the arrangement of physical objects (entities)."
children.name: Physical_Entity

children.description: "A physical object created by some person to fulfill a particular purpose"
children.name: Artifact

children.description: "A natural object is an object not created by man."
children.name: Natural_Object

children.description: "The continuation of a change, once initiated"
children.name: Continuation

children.description: "The initation of a change"
children.name: Initiation

children.description: "An action is a change which is brought about by a single agent, playing a role. The agent is the holder of some indended outcome of the action: an action is always intentional. The intention of the agent has usually corresponds with an expectation the intended outcome to be brought about: the agent believes in some expectation. Note that the intention might not correspond with the *actual* outcome of the action."
children.name: Action

children.description: "An act which results in the creation of some entity/individual"
children.name: Creation

children.description: "A speech act (or illocutionary act) creates some propositional attitude which qualifies an expression (which by default is mediated through some medium). The actor of the speech act is the utterer of the atitude (NB cannot be expressed in OWL DL)."
children.name: Speech_Act

children.description: "A reaction is an action that is (at least) performed by an agent that has observed some other action (this is an intensional view): Action <-> Reaction"
children.name: Reaction

children.description: "The termination of a change."
children.name: Termination

children.description: "A dynamic temporal entity represents the norm in its evolution over time."
children.name: Dynamic_Temporal_Entity

children.description: "The date when a modification is applied to the destination legislative document. The date can be instantaneous, in the future or in the past. Normally this date coincides with the date of efficacy of the text in which the modification takes place."
children.name: Application_Date

children.description: "This is the interval during which a normative document, or fragment, produces the consequences that the normative provision establishes."
children.name: Application_Interval

children.description: "The period during which a normative fragment may be either operative or inoperative, by explicit provision of the document itself. The document is said to be in a period of operation, or enforceability or efficacy, when it may or must be applied or enforced."
children.name: Efficacy_Interval

children.description: "The period during which a normative fragment belongs to the normative system. The period of force for each fragment may change over time as a function of the modifications the document goes through."
children.name: In_Force_Interval

children.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"
children.name: Modification

children.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"
children.name: Semantic_Annotation

children.description: "A modification that changes the meaning of some provision without changing its literal text"
children.name: Modification_of_Meaning

children.description: "Modification of the interpretation of normative content by the author or some superior actor"
children.name: Interpretation

children.description: "Modification of the term specified by some procedural deadline."
children.name: Modification_of_Term

children.description: "Modification by paraphrasing"
children.name: Variation

children.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"
children.name: Modification_of_Scope

children.description: "Extends the scope of normative content to some particular jurisdiction"
children.name: Extension

children.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"
children.name: Modification_of_System

children.description: "When a local act applies in the local legal system normative supra-ordered such as when a region applies an EU directive or a decree it applies the normative contant in some act"
children.name: Application

children.description: "When a part of some primary legislative source is delegated to some secondary legislative source (e.g. from act to regulation). "
children.name: Deregulation

children.description: "When an international treaty is ratified by local parliament in order to include it in the local legal system. The same thing happens when each local parliament ratifies bilateral or multilateral agreements."
children.name: Ratification

children.description: "When an act is completely rewritten in a new way but the topic remains the same."
children.name: Remaking

children.description: "Interpretation in context of the European Union"
children.name: Transposition

children.description: "Modifies the efficacy or being in force of some norm"
children.name: Temporal_Modification

children.description: "Modifies the efficacy period of some norm"
children.name: Efficacy_Modification

children.description: "Prorogation of entry into force, but applied to the efficacy of some norm"
children.name: Prorogation_Efficacy

children.description: "When the efficacy or a partial efficacy starts before the entry into force of the document"
children.name: Retroactivity

children.description: "When a part of an act or some provisions are suspended in coming to be operative for a period or indefinately"
children.name: Suspension

children.description: "Modifies the period of being in force of some norm"
children.name: In_Force_Modification

children.description: "When an act states the end of the period of enactment, and includes an implicit repealing of the text."
children.name: End_in_Force

children.description: "Prorogation of the date of enactment of some normative content. The 'life' of the act is lengthened with respect to some previous end of enactment modification."
children.name: Prorogation_in_Force

children.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"
children.name: Textual_Modification

children.description: "Moving some part of the text to some other place within the same document"
children.name: Relocation

children.description: "Removal of some part of text or the entire act from the legal system."
children.name: Repeal

children.description: "Substitution of a part or entire act or annex"
children.name: Substitution

children.description: "A static temporal entity captures a single moment in the norm's life that is fixed over time."
children.name: Static_Temporal_Entity

children.description: "The date when the competent authorities finalise the document by affixing their signatures to it (e.g. promulgation by the president, signature by the queen etc.) This is the date shown on the document itself: it is an objective element and clearly identifyable."
children.name: Delivery_Date

children.description: "The date when a dnormative document becomes law and enters the legal system for the first time. This is the moment in the doucment's history starting from which the document can be amended, its applicability assessed, and its manner of producing an effect determined."
children.name: Enter_in_Force_Date

children.description: "The date when the normative document is published in the official journal designated as the source for making all such documents public and legal."
children.name: Publication_Date
